project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to replace 94 streetlamps with LED lighting fixtures. The town of Ossipee is a smaller community of just over 4,000 residents in the center east of New Hampshire, ideally situated between the White Mountains and Lakes Regions. This quintessential New England town, with a proud manufacturing history and six villages, has strategically planned to build public infrastructure, recreational assets and sustainability policy to attract new residents, businesses and visitors. project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to build a new public works building in the town of Groton, New Hampshire. Groton is a small town located in Grafton County with a population of less than 600. Their public works building is located in a FEMA-designated floodplain and has experienced six different flood events since 2005, causing widescale damage that gets worse with each storm. Along with the flood damage to the building, the equipment, tools and supplies stored in the town garage also become damaged and destroyed. The facilities are aging and are well past their useful lives; so the town plans to construct a new building that would be built on suitable land outside the flood zone. The Groton Public Works Department provides services to the town such as road construction, maintenance, plowing and sanding; it also maintains and stores the highway departments vehicles, equipment, materials, and tools. The pre-engineered steel building will include four bays for maintenance and vehicle storage, an office for the road agent, a staff breakroom, a restroom with a shower, a tool storage room and mechanical room.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase medical equipment at Cottage Hospital, an independent, critical-access hospital (CAH) located in Woodsville, New Hampshire. The facility offers 24-hour emergency services, an inpatient unit, surgical services, specialty care and several outpatient services. Their primary service area of approximately 21,000 people is comprised of 13 economically depressed towns between New Hampshire and Vermont. Like many non-profit CAHs across the country, Cottage Hospital struggles financially due to low reimbursement and the rising costs of quality health care. However, they are committed to provide their patients and community the care needed regardless of ability to pay. To that end, Cottage Hospital gives over $2 million of free care and benefits each year. The past year has been especially tumultuous: along the uncertainties and obstacles of the global pandemic, they also experienced a devastating flood caused by torrential rain and failed drainage on July 14, 2020. This left their surgical suites non-operational for a month. The financial impact to the facility was vast. The hospital beds slated to be funded by this grant are essential pieces of equipment to support the mission to strengthen the health of our community by providing accessible, compassionate, quality health care.

project_name: FY21 Well and Water Line Rep
naics_industry_sector: Utilities (22)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to establish a well, expand the chemical feed building, and replace water main lines in Lisbon, New Hampshire. The well will replace one that has been out of service due to persistent coliform bacteria. This has left the town with only one well for supply, and it doesnt have an emergency power backup. The improvements to the chemical feed building will provide modern technology to monitor and control chemical treatments. The water lines will replace 3,600 linear feet of leaky, oversized, cast-iron pipes that range in age from 30 to 60 years. The system currently loses as much as 40 percent of its water to leakage. As a result of this project, the town will have a more secure, reliable and efficient water system. Lisbon is a small community with limited financial resources and a median household income well below that of the states. Without this investment, the town would not be able to make these improvements on its own. The town previously received a $30,000 grant for planning this project.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to update and replace the utility infrastructure for the Colebrook Homeowners Cooperative (CHC), a manufactured housing community located in Colebrook, New Hampshire. CHC is an important affordable-housing option in rural Colebrook, with 47 total lots and 26 homes currently occupied. Manufactured housing communities offer an affordable housing option in New Hampshire which is greatly needed to maintain the workforce employers are desperately seeking. The Colebrook Homeowners Cooperative joint USDA Rural Development Community Facility and Water and Environmental Program funding for this project addresses combined water, sewer, storm water and utility infrastructure upgrades. It will also provide age-related needs like reduction of pollution and health hazards due to significant leaks and corrosion in the electric system. project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase a mobile clinic van as part of the Northern New Hampshire Mobile Clinic Program serving Northern Coos County. This mobile clinic van will extend community healthcare by fostering immunization and preventative screening services at often-underutilized local sites across rural northern New Hampshire. It will also include a focus on COVID-19 initial vaccinations and boosters, monoclonal antibody treatment or pop-up COVID-19 testing. This project was built through community collaboration between multiple hospitals and providers, local insurance carrier and businesses, public charities and agencies, and the NH Medical Society. The cross-section of healthcare organizations involved with the project will increase access to needed health care in the communities involved, including telemedicine capabilities to patients with no internet access close to their home. This project will improve the quality and safety of the patient care environment and relieve a significant stressor for clinical and facilities staff.

project_name: FY 22 SOLAR AT EDWARD FENN ELE
naics_industry_sector: Educational Services (61)
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to install a 100-kilowatt ground mounted solar array at the Edward Fenn Elementary School to offset roughly 80-90 perecent of the electricity use at the school in Gorham, New Hampshire. The school is part of the Gorham Randolph Shelburne Cooperative School District, and this project is phase two of the effort in Gorham to convert to renewable and efficient energy use. The project supports the town of Gorhams Master Plan adopted in late 2019, incorporating energy efficiency and renewable energy goals for the rural community of 2,848. This solar array project builds on a Rural Development investment in FY 20 for LED lighting in the school system. The LED project lowered energy usage, and this project will provide the renewable energy for the lower energy needs. This project is expected to produce 127,000 kilowatt hours of electricity, and over the next 25 years nearly 3 million kilowatt hours which is equivalent to 4.6 million pounds of avoided carbon dioxide emissions. These cost savings will help reduce the operational cost of the organization, freeing up funds for curriculum development and greater learning opportunities for students. Every dollar saved on energy is a dollar that can stay within the school system and be redirected in ways that benefit the community.

naics_description: OTHER FIRE/RESCUE & PUBLIC SAFETY RELATED SERVICES
project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase an off-road rescue vehicle that can access injured people or reach fires in the hundreds of miles of recreational trails and logging roads within the Stratford Hollow Fire Department service area (population of 1066 including adjacent portions of Maidstone and Brunswick, Vermont). The Town of Stratford is a rural community of approximately 681 people located in Coos County, and has repurposed the hundreds of trails and logging roads as outdoor recreational areas after the manufacturing and timber industry left the area. These trails require off-road vehicles to reach hikers who need emergency assistance, allowing for quicker rescues as well as wildfire mitigation. The new vehicle will be a multi-person utility task vehicle that can be used year-round to provide rescue services, transport first responder personnel and equipment to rescue scenes, and transport patients as needed. The unit will be equipped with a track system for winter use. Currently the department has no off-road vehicle and must rely on mutual aid for access to rescue scenes, which may delay medical services to the residents.

project_announced_description: This Rural Development investment will be used to install a 50-kilowatt solar array at the Stratford Transfer Station, which will offset the electricity usage for the majority of the Stratford municipal accounts, including the Transfer Station, Fire Station, Library, streetlights, and sewer and pump stations. This northern New Hampshire community of 746 has a commitment to using renewable energy, and this project is a culmination of previous projects in Stratford including solar panels on the town hall and LED replacement in the town hall and fire station. The project at the Transfer Station is projected to produce roughly 59,000 kilowatt hours of electricity in year one, equivalent to offsetting 92,000 pounds of carbon dioxide per year. Over 25 years the solar array is projected to produce 1.3 million kilowatt hours of electricity and save the town $138,700 with a 6-year payback expectation.
